title: SB 1159
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to make cost, quality, and equity data available to encourage innovative healthcare approaches in California. A data atlas will be used to assess healthcare needs, control costs, improve quality, reduce disparities, increase transparency, and promote wellness programs. The California Health and Human Services Agency is tasked with researching the development of a cost, quality, and equity data atlas to improve healthcare outcomes and reduce disparities. The California Health and Human Services Agency is researching the development of a cost, quality, and equity data atlas, including identifying key data submitters and analyzing potential models from other states. The California Health and Human Services Agency is researching the development of a cost, quality, and equity data atlas. A comparative analysis of potential models used in other states is being conducted to determine the inclusion of additional data elements such as health care claims data and pricing information for meaningful comparisons of provider prices and treatment costs. The California Health and Human Services Agency is researching the development of a cost, quality, and equity data atlas. The data atlas will include information on social determinants of health, clinical data from various healthcare providers, governance structures, and funding approaches. The California Health and Human Services Agency is conducting research on a cost, quality, and equity data atlas. The agency will assess funding approaches, consult with stakeholders, and make the research results public by March 1, 2017. The agency may use federal funds for this purpose.
